column6: Robert Gordon|In the summer of 1968
column7: television news changed forever. Dead last in the ratings
column8: ABC hired two towering public intellectuals to debate each other during the Democratic and Republican national conventions. William F. Buckley
column9: Jr. was a leading light of the new conservative movement. A Democrat and cousin to Jackie Onassis
column10: Gore Vidal was a leftist novelist and polemicist. Armed with deep-seated distrust and enmity
column11: Vidal and Buckley believed each other's political ideologies were dangerous for America. Like rounds in a heavyweight battle
column12: they pummeled out policy and personal insult-cementing their opposing political positions. Their explosive exchanges devolved into vitriolic name-calling. It was unlike anything TV had ever broadcast
column13: and all the more shocking because it was live and unscripted. Viewers were riveted. ABC News' ratings skyrocketed. And a new era in public discourse was born - a highbrow blood sport that marked the dawn of pundit television as we know it today. (C) Magnolia|7.6/10|116|109|7|7.4/10|35|32|3|4/5|6

column1: 771415352|My Italian Secret: The Forgotten Heroes|Oren Jacoby|Art House & International
column6: 2015||NR|92|The Film Sales Company|Oren Jacoby|MY ITALIAN SECRET tells a heroic story that was all but lost to history
column7: until now. The film recounts how WWII bicycling idol Gino Bartali
column8: physician Giovanni Borromeo and other Italians worked with Jewish leaders and high-ranking officials of the Catholic Church
column9: risking their lives by defying the Nazis to save thousands of Italy's Jews. Their high-risk methods were ingenious. Bartali
column10: a Tour de France champion
column11: criss-crossed Northern Italy transporting fake identification documents in the frame of his bicycle. A physician
column12: Dr. Borromeo
column13: invented a fictitious disease to scare the SS away from the hospital where he was hiding Jews. Others disguised Jewish girls and women as nuns and hid them in convents. In this epic documentary
column14: living characters return to Italy to reveal their stories
column15: and to thank those who were willing to sacrifice their own lives to save strangers without ever seeking recognition or reward for their courage. Oscar (R)-nominated director Oren Jacoby resurrects the dramatic story of this secret underground
column16: giving it the attention it so richly deserves. (C) The Film Sales Company|7.2/10|5|4|1|||||3.9/5|196

column1: 771416830|Winning: The Racing Life Of Paul Newman|Nate Adams
column5: 2015||NR|83|FilmBuff|Adam Carolla
column6: Nate Adams|The world knows Paul Newman as an Academy Award winning actor with a fifty-plus year career as one of the most prolific and revered actors in American Cinema. He was also well known for his philanthropy Newman's Own has given more than four hundred and thirty million dollars to charities around the world. Yet few know the gasoline-fueled passion that became so important in this complex
column7: multifaceted man's makeup. Newman's deep seeded passion for racing was so intense it nearly sidelined his acting career. His racing career spanned thirty-five years Newman won four national championships as a driver and eight championships as an owner. Not bad for a guy who didn't even start racing until he was forty-seven years old.|7/10|10|9|1|7.7/10|5|5|0|4.5/5|1
